```java
import java.awt.event.KeyEvent;
import java.awt.event.KeyListener;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;

public class Example implements KeyListener {
    private Map<Integer, Long> keyPressTimes = new HashMap<>();

    public void keyTyped(KeyEvent e) {}

    public void keyPressed(KeyEvent e) {
        if (!keyPressTimes.containsKey(e.getKeyCode())) {
            System.out.println("KeyPressed: "+e.getKeyCode()+", ts="+e.getWhen());
            keyPressTimes.put(e.getKeyCode(), e.getWhen());
        }
    }

    public void keyReleased(KeyEvent e) {
        if (keyPressTimes.get(e.getKeyCode()) != null) {
            System.out.println("KeyReleased: "+e.getKeyCode()+", ts="+e.getWhen());
            keyPressTimes.remove(e.getKeyCode());
        }
    }
}
```

<<<explanation>>>: 
In this code, we use a HashMap to store the timestamp of when each key is pressed. When a key is pressed, we first check if the key code is already in the map. If it is not, we print the key press event and add the key code and timestamp to the map. When a key is released, we check if the key code is in the map. If it is, we print the key release event and remove the key code from the map. This way, we ignore any repeated key press events for the same key code, and only print the first key press event and the corresponding key release event. This should work on all platforms, including Linux, Mac OS and Windows.
